--- title: "ALMA Scorecard Hub" description: "This is a digital platform developed by the African Leaders Malaria Alliance (ALMA) to track and support progress towards malaria elimination." date: 10/01/2024 # mm-dd-yyyy image: "images/alma-scorecard.png" lightbox: true execute: message: false warning: false language: title-block-published: "Last updated" page-layout: full title-block-banner: "#EDF3F9" title-block-banner-color: "#212529" categories: - malaria - country scorecards - indicators - country-level - accountability --- ::: {.page-tabs .panel-tabset} ## Overview

About the data

- The site uses two languages, namely, *English* and *French*. - The data is presented in the form of scorecards showing several indicators that are used to assess a country's health priorities. - Indicators may vary from country to country, countries generally choose indicators based on their national health strategies. - There are currently: 40 malaria country level tools, 1 country level scorecard tool that combines malaria and neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). - There are 3 types of scorecards available: country scorecards, community scorecards and the ALMA scorecard for accountability and action. - The country scorecard provides a snapshot of a country's health performance. - The community scorecard provides a means for assessing the quality of health services offered at the local health facility or catchment area. - The ALMA scorecard for accountability and action displays country level performance against key indicators, highlighting successes and shortfalls.

Accessing the data

- To view the available scorecards visit [Scorecard management tools](https://scorecardhub.org/scorecards/). - No login credentials are needed to view or download the available scorecards - Login credentials are needed if an individual wishes to undertake any of the [online courses](https://scorecardhub.org/online-courses) offered by ALMA. - Under the tab country scorecards, a search can be refined through the use of available filters. The filters are for *country*, *scorecard type* and *year*. To access the scorecards on *malaria*, use the filter *scorecard type* and choose any of the following depending on specific context (*Malaria*, *ALMA Scorecard for Accountability on Action*, *Commonwealth Malaria Tracker*) from the drop-down menu. - Under the tab country best practices, a search can be refined through the use of available filters. The filters are for *search*, *topic*, *types of best practices*, *country* and *year*. To access best practices for malaria, use the filter *topic*, 2 choices are available: *Malaria scorecard tools* and *End malaria councils* from the drop-down menu. - The video below demonstrates how to navigate the site: ::: {.callout-note collapse="true"} ## Video demonstration of the ALMA Scorecard Hub {{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jJAk_A0bfyk >}} :::

What does the data look like?

- Some scorecards are shared as pdf files (these are downloadable) ![Rwanda Malaria Scorecard](images/pdf_scorecard.png) or directly from the web platform (not downloadable, user has to scroll through the file) ![Zambia Malaria Scorecard](images/web_platform%20scorecard.png) - Scorecards are color coded, the main colors of use are *green (on track)*, *yellow (in progress)*, *red (not on track)*, *grey (not applicable or no data)*, *white (no data)*. - Scorecards use arrows in combination with the colors, *up arrow (to show an increase)* and *down arrow (to show a decrease)*. - The ALMA scorecards for accountability and action gives the ALMA scorecard, the Africa Summary report and country specific reports as pdfs in any one of the following languages, *English*, *Arabic*, *Spanish*, *French*, *Swahili* and *Portuguese*. - Data available is for the years 2015 to 2024.

Key points to consider

- Downloading the [materials](https://scorecardhub.org/guides-and-toolkits/download-course-content-to-access-when-you-do-not-have-an-internet-connection/) for the online courses is highly beneficial, as they provide a comprehensive overview on how to create scorecards. This will help towards the understanding and interpretation of the scorecards. - The scorecards are highly country specific, indicators change according to the country's health priorities. ## Visualisations

How to use this data

- As indicators vary across countries, it is necessary to check if the indicators of interest are within the available scorecards. - It is also necessary to check if the country of interest has made the country scorecard available. - As the scorecards are available in pdf format or as a web platform, information has to be extracted manually.

How to plot this data?

::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # load the libraries library(ggrepel) library(sf) library(rnaturalearth) library(rnaturalearthdata) library(readxl) library(stringr) library(dplyr) source(here::here("radar/theme_health_radar.R")) # Define the Rwanda provinces rwanda_provinces <- c("East", "South", "West", "North", "Kigali city") # Load the map data for Rwanda rwanda_map <- ne_states(country = "Rwanda", returnclass = "sf") %>% mutate(name = rwanda_provinces) # Read in data rwandap_data <- read_excel("rwanda_q1_provinces2022.xlsx") cases <- rwandap_data$MalariaTotalCases # Merge the map data with your data rwanda_data <- rwanda_map %>% left_join(rwandap_data, by = c("name" = "province")) # Create the choropleth map ggplot(data = rwanda_data) + geom_sf(aes(fill = cases), color = "lightgrey", size = 0.3) + # Use fill for the continuous 2022 data theme_health_radar() + scale_fill_continuous_health_radar(name = "Total Cases") + # Correct fill scale for continuous data labs( title = "Reported malaria cases Rwanda (by province) 1st quarter (2022)", caption = str_wrap("The choropleth map highlights the total number of new outpatient department (OPD) cases of malaria recorded at health facilities in the five provinces of Rwanda during the first quarter of 2022. With the East and South provinces showing the lowest and highest number of cases respectively. Source: ALMA Scorecard Hub, Scorecard management tool.", width = 80), x = "Latitude", y = "Longitude" ) + geom_sf_text( aes(label = name, color = ifelse(cases > mean(cases), "black", "white")), size = 3 ) + # Conditional text color scale_color_identity() + theme(plot.caption.position = "plot") # Keep the caption outside the plot area ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](alma_scorecards_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Creating the data frame Country <- c("Angola", "Angola", "Angola", "Botswana", "Botswana", "Botswana", "Eswatini", "Eswatini", "Eswatini", "Mozambique", "Mozambique", "Mozambique", "Namibia", "Namibia", "Namibia", "South Africa", "South Africa", "South Africa", "Zambia", "Zambia", "Zambia", "Zimbabwe", "Zimbabwe", "Zimbabwe") Year <- rep(2023, 24) # Same year for all entries Quarter <- rep(1:3, times = 8) # Three quarters for each country Operational_LLINS_IRS <- c(58, 62, 56, # Angola 0, 66, 66, # Botswana 90, 91, 91, # Eswatini 100, 100, 100, # Mozambique 64, 64, 64, # Namibia 70, 86, 86, # South Africa 88, 100, 100, # Zambia 94, 94, 94) # Zimbabwe # Create the data frame dataframe <- data.frame(Country, Year, Quarter, Operational_LLINS_IRS) # Display the dataframe dataframe ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Country Year Quarter Operational_LLINS_IRS 1 Angola 2023 1 58 2 Angola 2023 2 62 3 Angola 2023 3 56 4 Botswana 2023 1 0 5 Botswana 2023 2 66 6 Botswana 2023 3 66 7 Eswatini 2023 1 90 8 Eswatini 2023 2 91 9 Eswatini 2023 3 91 10 Mozambique 2023 1 100 11 Mozambique 2023 2 100 12 Mozambique 2023 3 100 13 Namibia 2023 1 64 14 Namibia 2023 2 64 15 Namibia 2023 3 64 16 South Africa 2023 1 70 17 South Africa 2023 2 86 18 South Africa 2023 3 86 19 Zambia 2023 1 88 20 Zambia 2023 2 100 21 Zambia 2023 3 100 22 Zimbabwe 2023 1 94 23 Zimbabwe 2023 2 94 24 Zimbabwe 2023 3 94 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Create a grouped bar plot ggplot(dataframe, aes(fill = as.factor(Quarter),y = Operational_LLINS_IRS, x = Country)) + geom_bar(position = "dodge", stat = "identity") + # Grouped bars by country and quarter scale_fill_manual_health_radar() + # Apply the custom scale fill for countries labs( title = "Operational LLINs/IRS Coverage by Country and Quarter (2023)", subtitle = "For Selected Countries", x = "Country", y = "LLINs/IRS Coverage (%)", fill = "Quarter", caption = str_wrap("The grouped bar plot shows operational LLINs/IRS coverage for selected countries in 2023. Each bar represents the percentage of the population at risk covered by operational LLINs/IRS, aiding in understanding coverage disparities across countries. Source: ALMA Scorecard Hub, ALMA Scorecard for Accountability on Action.", width = 80) ) + theme_health_radar() + # Apply the custom radar theme theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1)) # Rotate x-axis text for better visibility ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](alma_scorecards_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: :::

Tracking indicator perfomance

- The plot given below highlights how tracking indicator performance can be achieved. - Several country performances are highlighted using data obtained from ALMA scorecards for accountability and action. - The implementation indicator on operational vector control (LLINs/IRS) coverage was considered. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Read in data E8_data <- read_excel("E8_implementation.xlsx") E8_data$LLINs <- as.numeric(E8_data$LLINs) vc <- E8_data$LLINs country_colors <- c( "Angola" = "#6a3d9a", # Dark Purple "Botswana" = "#66a61e", # Dark Green "Eswatini" = "#7570b3", # Medium Purple "Mozambique" = "#ffff99", # Pale Yellow "Namibia" = "#d95f02", # Dark Orange "South Africa" = "#1f78b4", # Blue "Zambia" = "#e7298a", # Pink "Zimbabwe" = "#e6ab02" # Mustard Yellow ) # Create the ggplot ggplot(E8_data, aes(x = Year, y = vc, group = Country)) + # Add background panels geom_rect(aes(xmin = -Inf, xmax = Inf, ymin = 0, ymax = 40), fill = "#e31a1c", alpha = 0.2) + geom_rect(aes(xmin = -Inf, xmax = Inf, ymin = 40, ymax = 80), fill = "yellow", alpha = 0.2) + geom_rect(aes(xmin = -Inf, xmax = Inf, ymin = 80, ymax = 100), fill = "#33a02c", alpha = 0.2) + # Add lines in a fixed color geom_line(color = "black", size = 0.5) + # Set line color to blue (or any desired color) # Distinguish points by country geom_point(aes(color = Country), size = 1.5) + scale_color_manual(values = country_colors) + # Apply manual color scale for 'color' aesthetic (points) scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 100, by = 10)) + # Set y-axis breaks from 0 to 100 at intervals of 10 scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2015, 2024, by = 1)) + # Set x-axis breaks for each year theme_health_radar() + labs( title = "Vector Control Implementation (2015-2024)", x = "Year", y = "% Coverage", color = "Country", caption = str_wrap("The plot displays operational LLINs/IRS coverage (% at risk population) in selected countries from 2015 to 2023, with lines representing the coverage trend across 4 quarters per year. The red, yellow and green panels indicate country level perfomace against the implementation indicator for vector control.Stable trends in the green panel for some countries indicate that they are on track while others show fluctuations over the years. Source: ALMA Scorecard Hub, ALMA Scorecard for Accountability on Action.", width = 85) ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](alma_scorecards_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: :::
